Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Exploratory and novel mechanisms of cytoskeleton-induced regulation of Sirt1 in smooth muscles

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1156307/ Boriek

This EAGER award funded by the Biotechnology, Biochemical and Biomass Engineering Program will use engineering tools to explore a novel and controverial hypothesis about the mechanism of signal transduction in smooth muscle cells. The hypothesis involves the role of the cytoskeleton in regulating mechanosensing genes in these cells. Exploratory data generated from the proposed experiments in this developmental research project could provide for the first time fundamental innovative information on a novel signaling role of specific cytoskeletal elements in the regulation of the silent information regulator 1 (Sirt1) in smooth muscle cells. The research will engage an interdisciplinary team of experts in bioengineering, physiology, biophysics, and molecular biology.

The long term objective of the work is to contribute to the understanding of the molecular physiological mechanisms modulating airway smooth muscle dysfunction in asthma, and to uncover innovative molecular mechanisms that could potentially alter interventional approaches for preventing and treating asthma. Results from the proposed EAGER may provide novel exploratory data that could potentially contribute to guide interventional approaches for preventing and treating asthma, and improve the quality of life in asthmatics.

The award will integrate research and education in science, molecular biology, and biochemistry, and physiology by directly engaging undergraduate, graduate, and possibly medical students. It will encourage students to participate as well as organize scientific
meetings. The PI will attract undergraduates through Baylor College of Medicine SMART Program that supports under-represented students to pursue research careers initially as undergraduates. The PI will also contribute to the training of graduate students at the interface between engineering, biology and medicine.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Impact in the field: The focus of this EAGER grant was to explore a novel signaling role of desmin intermediate filaments in modulating smooth muscle func­tion. It is important to recognize that our own published work established that desmin is a modulator of airway smooth muscle contractility (Shardonofsky et al. 2006). In addition, other investigators have discov­ered that desmin expression is altered in the airway smooth muscles of asthmatics (Slats et al., 2008). Furthermore, other investigators have found that inhibition of Sirt1 attenuated antigen-induced airway inflammation and hyperresponsiveness (Kim et al. 2010). Taken together, these studies provided a strong rationale for our focus on innovative exploratory aspects of a possible signaling role of desmin in modulating Sirt1 expression through mecha­nosensing signaling pathways in airway smooth muscles.  In this project, we will explore the idea of whether the disturbance of the desmin gene expression in smooth muscle cells can cause upregulation of Sirt1 expression and whether the mechanosensing transcription factor NF-kappaB is involved in such regulation.  Our proposed studies have the potential to contribute to uncover for the first time possible signaling mechanisms that are involved in the regulation of either the stretch-induced or desmin-induced activities of Sirt1 in smooth muscle cells.

 Impact on other disciplines: We recognized early in our research efforts that the central idea of this application could be tested in both skeletal muscles and cardiac muscles. We have already tested the idea of mechanical regulation of Sirt1 in the skeletal muscles of the diaphragm, and our hope to uncover whether the cytoskeleton is involved in modulating the mechanosensing signaling pathways in the diaphragm. It is important to recognize that Sirt1 is a critically important gene in skeletal muscle physiology. Our recent discovery that the interaction between EGR1 and SIRT1 describes an autoregulatory loop that shuts down the stretch-induced Sirt1 expression would be critically important in the field of mechanotransduction in skeletal muscle.

Broader impact: Our long term objective is to contribute to our understanding of the role of the cytoskeleton molecular physiological mechanisms modulating muscle function. The proposed research provided new information on signaling mechanisms that are involved in the disruption of the cytoskeletal elements of smooth and skeletal muscle cells. Our project was designed to integrate research and education in science, molecular biology, and biochemistry, and physiology by directly engaging undergraduate, and post-doctoral research associates in the proposed research. Our discoveries highlighted a novel signaling role of intermediate filaments in modulating the activity of the Sirt1 gene. We attracted undergraduates through Baylor College of Medicine SMART Program that supports under-represented students to pursue research careers initially as undergraduates. We published our discoveries in traditional rigorously-reviewed scientific journals.
